title: Timothée Chalamet's Promotional Strategy and Cultural Picks
summary: Timothée Chalamet, a prominent Hollywood actor, is engaging in a unique promotional campaign for his upcoming film 'Marty Supreme', a 1950s table tennis movie. As part of this effort, he is compiling a list of five Brits he considers all-time greats, which includes figures like Lewis Hamilton, David and Victoria Beckham, underground rapper Fakemink, and surprisingly, Susan Boyle. He expresses genuine admiration for Boyle, recalling her viral 2009 performance on Britain's Got Talent that moved many during the early days of YouTube. Chalamet explains that Boyle 'dreamt bigger than all of us,' using her story to connect with audiences. To promote the film, he has been presenting custom jackets with the movie's title to individuals he deems great, such as athletes Michael Phelps and Tom Brady, and footballer Lamine Yamal. Currently in London, he has opened a pop-up store and is conducting interviews from a hotel overlooking Hyde Park, blending celebrity culture with marketing tactics to generate buzz for his project.

background_read: Timothée Chalamet is a 29-year-old actor known for roles in films like 'Call Me by Your Name' and 'Dune'. He is promoting 'Marty Supreme', a movie set in the 1950s about table tennis, using creative marketing like listing admired Brits to engage fans. Susan Boyle rose to fame in 2009 on Britain's Got Talent with her performance of 'I Dreamed a Dream', becoming a global sensation and symbol of dreaming big. Chalamet's strategy reflects how celebrities use social media and personal stories to build hype for projects, connecting with audiences through shared cultural moments.
